title: Higher-Level Review Guide
when_to_use:
File a Higher-Level Review when you believe the VA made an ERROR with the evidence they already had.

Good situations for Higher-Level Review:
- The VA ignored evidence in your file (like a nexus letter)
- The rating specialist miscalculated your combined rating
- The VA used the wrong diagnostic code for your condition
- Your C&P exam results were misinterpreted
- The VA didn't apply the 'benefit of the doubt' rule
- The examiner's findings weren't reflected in the decision
- The VA ordered an unnecessary exam for a presumptive condition

The key: You're NOT submitting new evidence. You're asking a senior reviewer to look at the SAME evidence with fresh eyes.
when_not_to_use:
Do NOT file a Higher-Level Review if:

- You have new evidence to submit (use Supplemental Claim instead)
- Your case needs new evidence to win (HLR won't help without it)
- You want to present your case in person with new evidence (use Board Appeal)
- You already filed an HLR for this decision (can only file one per decision)

Higher-Level Review is ONLY for correcting errors. If your claim was denied because you're missing evidence (like a nexus letter), getting that evidence and filing a Supplemental Claim is better.
overview:
A Higher-Level Review asks a more senior VA employee to take a fresh look at your claim using the SAME evidence that was already in your file. No new evidence is allowed.

This is the best option when you believe the VA made a mistake - maybe they ignored a medical opinion, used the wrong rating criteria, or made a calculation error.

The average processing time is about 141 days. If the reviewer finds an error, they can either correct it themselves or return your claim (called a 'remand') for additional work.

**Important:** You can only file ONE Higher-Level Review per decision. If it's denied, your options are Supplemental Claim (with new evidence) or Board Appeal.
requirements:
To file a Higher-Level Review, you need:

**Required:**
- VA Form 20-0996 (Decision Review Request: Higher-Level Review)
- Filed within 1 year of your decision date

**Optional but Recommended:**
- Request an Informal Conference (phone call with the reviewer)
- Written statement identifying the specific error(s)

**What You CANNOT Include:**
- New evidence
- New medical records
- New nexus letters
- New buddy statements

If you try to submit new evidence with an HLR, it will NOT be considered. The reviewer only looks at what was already in your file.
step_by_step:
**Step 1: Identify the Error**
Review your decision letter and claim file. What did the VA get wrong? Be specific:
- Did they ignore a document?
- Did they misapply a regulation?
- Did they make a math error?
- Did they use wrong criteria?

**Step 2: Complete VA Form 20-0996**
Fill out the form:
- Check 'Higher-Level Review'
- List the issues/conditions you're appealing
- Request an Informal Conference (recommended)
- Note the same office or different office preference

**Step 3: Prepare for Informal Conference (if requested)**
This is your chance to talk to the reviewer:
- Prepare talking points about the specific errors
- Have your decision letter ready
- Be ready to point to specific evidence in your file
- Be concise and factual

**Step 4: Submit the Form**
Submit VA Form 20-0996:
- Online at VA.gov
- By mail to your regional office
- In person
- Through your VSO

**Step 5: Wait for Conference Call**
If you requested an Informal Conference, you'll get a call. This usually happens within 30-60 days of filing.

**Step 6: Wait for Decision**
After the review (and conference if requested), the reviewer will issue a decision. Average time: ~141 days.
evidence_guidance:
**Remember: No New Evidence Allowed**

With a Higher-Level Review, you're asking the VA to re-examine evidence that's ALREADY in your file. The reviewer will look at:

**What's Already in Your File:**
- Your original claim and all submissions
- Service treatment records
- VA medical records
- Private medical records you submitted
- C&P exam reports
- Any nexus letters or opinions
- Buddy statements
- Previous rating decisions

**Your Job Is To Point Out Errors:**
Instead of gathering new evidence, document the specific errors:
- 'The decision ignored the nexus letter from Dr. Smith dated 5/15/2024'
- 'The rating used 38 CFR 4.71a instead of the correct 4.73'
- 'The C&P exam noted pain at 30 degrees but the decision said full ROM'

**If You Need New Evidence:**
If you realize your file is missing key evidence, STOP. File a Supplemental Claim instead. An HLR without the right evidence in your file will fail.
common_mistakes:
**Mistake 1: Filing HLR When You Need New Evidence**
If your claim was denied because you're missing a nexus letter, HLR won't help. You need to GET the nexus letter and file a Supplemental Claim.

**Mistake 2: Not Requesting an Informal Conference**
The Informal Conference is free and gives you a chance to explain the error directly to the reviewer. Always request it unless you have a good reason not to.

**Mistake 3: Being Vague About the Error**
Don't just say 'I disagree.' Identify the SPECIFIC error: what document, what date, what regulation, what calculation.

**Mistake 4: Trying to Submit New Evidence**
Any new evidence you include will be ignored. If you have new evidence, file a Supplemental Claim instead.

**Mistake 5: Missing the Informal Conference Call**
If you requested a conference, ANSWER THE PHONE. If you miss it, you may not get another chance. Make sure VA has your correct phone number.

**Mistake 6: Filing Multiple HLRs**
You can only file ONE Higher-Level Review per decision. If it fails, your options are Supplemental Claim or Board Appeal.

**Mistake 7: Not Reviewing Your Complete File**
Request your complete claim file (C-File) before filing. You need to know exactly what's in there to identify errors.
after_submission:
**What Happens After You Submit:**

**Week 1-4: Claim Received**
VA acknowledges receipt. If you requested an Informal Conference, you're added to the queue.

**Week 4-8: Informal Conference (if requested)**
A reviewer will call you. This is your chance to:
- Explain the error clearly
- Point to specific evidence in your file
- Ask questions

The call usually lasts 15-30 minutes. Be prepared and concise.

**Week 8-20: Senior Review**
The Higher-Level Reviewer examines your file with fresh eyes, looking for the errors you identified.

**Average Timeline: ~141 days**

**Possible Outcomes:**

- **Granted:** The reviewer found an error in your favor. You'll get a new rating.

- **Remanded:** The reviewer found problems but can't fix them directly. Your claim goes back for additional work (like a new C&P exam). This is often positive.

- **Denied:** The reviewer found no error. You can:
  - File a Supplemental Claim with new evidence
  - Appeal to the Board of Veterans' Appeals

**Note:** A remand isn't a denial - it often leads to approval after the additional work is done.
tips:
**Pro Tips for Higher-Level Review:**

1. **Always Request the Informal Conference**
This is your chance to speak directly with the decision-maker. Use it. Come prepared with specific points.

2. **Get Your C-File First**
Request your complete claim file before filing. You can't argue about errors if you don't know what's in your file.

3. **Be Specific About Errors**
General complaints don't work. Point to specific documents, dates, and regulations. 'The decision on page 3 ignored the DBQ finding of painful motion at 30 degrees' is effective.

4. **Use a VSO**
VSOs can help identify errors you might miss. They know the regulations and can spot mistakes in how your claim was processed.

5. **Prepare for the Conference Call**
Write down your points beforehand. Have your decision letter and notes ready. Be respectful but firm about the errors.

6. **Know When HLR Isn't Right**
If the problem is missing evidence (not an error with existing evidence), file a Supplemental Claim instead. HLR can't add what isn't there.

7. **Keep the Call Professional**
The reviewer wants to help, but they can only work with what's in your file. Stay calm, be factual, and focus on the specific errors.

8. **Understand Remand**
A remand isn't a loss - it means the reviewer found something wrong. The additional work often leads to approval.

checklist_items.task: Request your complete VA claim file (C-File) if you don't have it
Review your decision letter and identify SPECIFIC errors
Confirm you have no new evidence (if you do, consider Supplemental Claim instead)
Write down the specific errors with document names and dates
Check the box to request an Informal Conference
Verify your phone number is correct on the form
Submit VA Form 20-0996 (do NOT include new evidence)
Save confirmation number and submission date
Prepare talking points for Informal Conference
Keep phone available for conference call (check voicemail daily)
After call, document what was discussed

informal_conference_tips.what_it_is: A phone call with the Higher-Level Reviewer assigned to your case
informal_conference_tips.purpose: To identify specific errors in how your claim was decided
tips: Have your decision letter and notes in front of you
Be specific: 'Page 3 of my decision ignores...' not 'They got it wrong'
Stay calm and professional - the reviewer wants to help
Ask questions if something is unclear
Don't argue - just clearly state the errors you've identified
